description: From Middle English handsum, hondsom, equivalent to hand +‎ -some. Compare Dutch handzaam, German Low German handsaam. The original sense was ‘easy to handle or use’, hence ‘suitable’ and ‘apt, clever’ (mid 16th century), giving rise to the current appreciatory senses (late 16th century).

adjectives.description: handsome (comparative more handsome or handsomer, superlative most handsome or handsomest)

definitionGroups.group: Having a pleasing appearance, good-looking, attractive, particularly

entries.meaning: (now of a man or boy) Attractively manly, having a pleasing face and overall effect.
examples: I was struck dumb. Here was the most handsome man I'd ever seen in my life, repeatedly tripping over his own feet coming in out of the surf.

entries.meaning: (now of a woman) Statuesque, beautiful in a masculine or otherwise imposing way.
examples: She was either handsome or her uniform created a flattering effect but—being very nearsighted—he couldn't tell from this distance.
Sunday, the sixth, we heaved up our sheet-anchor again, the day beginning with little wind, and continued handsome weather till eight at night, when the wind came to S. S. W. and it fell a snowing.

entries.meaning: Suitable or fit in action; marked with propriety and ease; appropriate.
(obsolete, said of things and people) Dexterous; skillful.

verbs.description: handsome (third-person singular simple present handsomes, present participle handsoming, simple past and past participle handsomed)
